UK letter to EU's Tusk triggering Brexit process Pitas (2017) Wed Mar 29, states that: Below is the text of the letter British Prime Minister Theresa May sent to European Council President Donald Tusk triggering Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty, the formal start of the process by which Britain will leave the European Union. Dear President Tusk,   On 23 June, last year, the people of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union.  As I have said before, that decision was no rejection of the values we share as fellow Europeans.  Nor was it an attempt to do harm to the European Union or any of the remaining member states.  On the contrary, the United Kingdom wants the European Union to succeed and prosper.  Instead, the referendum was a vote to restore, as we see it, our national self-determination. We are leaving the European Union, but we are not leaving Europe – and we want to remain committed partners and allies to our friends across the continent.   Earlier this month, the United Kingdom Parliament confirmed the result of the referendum by voting with clear and convincing majorities in both of its Houses for the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill.  The Bill was passed by Parliament on 13 March and it received Royal Assent from Her Majesty The Queen and became an Act of Parliament on 16 March.   Today, therefore, I am writing to give effect to the democratic decision of the people of the United Kingdom. I hereby notify the European Council in accordance with Article 50(2) of the Treaty on European Union of the United Kingdom’s intention to withdraw from the European Union.  In addition, in accordance with the same Article 50(2) as applied by Article 106a of the Treaty Establishing the European Atomic Energy Community, I hereby notify the European Council of the United Kingdom’s intention to withdraw from the European Atomic Energy Community. References in this letter to the European Union should therefore be taken to include a reference to the European Atomic Energy Community.   This letter sets out the approach of Her Majesty’s Government to the discussions we will have about the United Kingdom’s departure from the European Union and about the deep and special partnership we hope to enjoy – as your closest friend and neighbor – with the European Union once we leave.  We believe that these objectives are in the interests not only of the United Kingdom but of the European Union and the wider world too.      It is in the best interests of both the United Kingdom and the European Union that we should use the forthcoming process to deliver these objectives in a fair and orderly manner, and with as little disruption as possible on each side. We want to make sure that Europe remains strong and prosperous and is capable of projecting its values, leading in the world, and defending itself from security threats. We want the United Kingdom, through a new deep and special partnership with a strong European Union, to play its full part in achieving these goals. We therefore believe it is necessary to agree the terms of our future partnership alongside those of our withdrawal from the European Union.   The Government wants to approach our discussions with ambition, giving citizens and businesses in the United Kingdom and the European Union – and indeed from third countries around the world – as much certainty as possible, as early as possible (para. 1-7). 'You can still stop Brexit,' EU lawmakers to tell Britons Guarascio and Körkemeier (2017) Tue Mar 28, states that: Francesco Guarascio and Tom Körkemeier | BRUSSELS
European Union lawmakers want to tell Britons they can change their minds and stay in the EU after Prime Minister Theresa May triggers a two-year Brexit countdown on Wednesday. The European Parliament is drafting a resolution to respond to May's notice of withdrawal under Article 50 of the EU treaty. Senior lawmakers said it would stress London could still halt the process, as long as the other member states agreed. The resolution text is not yet final but the intent is to strengthen the hand of those in Britain who want to halt Brexit. "We do not want to close the door to common sense," Philippe Lamberts, Belgian co-leader of the Greens in the parliament, told reporters. A member of the Brexit team in the legislature, which will have to approve an exit treaty, Lamberts added: "There will be a reference to the revocability of Article 50." Elmar Brok, a member of the team from German Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democrats, also said there was such a reference in the draft resolution, to be agreed by party leaders on Wednesday and put to a vote in the legislature next week. Insisting Britain can U-turn enters hazy legal territory. It defies May, who says the process cannot be halted despite Brexit opponents' hopes of a new referendum or British parliamentary vote. And although EU officials disagree with May and have said the process can be stopped, with the consent of all states, they do not welcome Brussels lawmakers' bid to revive the issue (para. 1-7). The ties that have bound the U.K. to the EU since 1973 will start to unravel at around 1:30 p.m. in Brussels when Britain’s ambassador hands EU President Donald Tusk a hand-signed letter from Prime Minister Theresa May invoking Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, the legal exit mechanism. May will address lawmakers in London at about the same time. Nine months since Britons unexpectedly voted to leave, the phony war of what Brexit might look like will turn into a real battle over the complex terms of a settlement with 27 other governments. Enough lines over money, trade and immigration have been drawn to suggest a tough process with costs to both sides. "We’re moving from a U.K. monologue to a hard negotiation,” said Gregor Irwin, chief economist at Global Counsel, a consultancy, and a former official in the U.K. Foreign Office. “There’s going to be many upsets along the way" (para. 1-4). For the record (two comments of mine re: passporting and type of brexit): EU28: Primarily, the so-called 'passporting rights' allow financial institutions to provide banking services throughout the single market irrespective of which EU member state they are based in. EEA Members: The passport is also extended to members of the EEA, as they adopt all EU financial laws. Hence they have 'full equivalence'. Third countries: Parts of the passporting rights can be extended to third countries, if they achieve legal/regulatory equivalence (Switzerland is a notable example). However, not all parts of EU financial legislation are covered and equivalence can also be revoked. Upon leaving the European Union, Britain would naturally have ‘full equivalence’ and would be a prime candidate for EEA membership. However, as the jurisprudence of the EFTA (which is responsible for EEA members) is based on ECJ case law and leaving the ECJ’s jurisdiction is a primary goal of Brexit this is problematic. 
Britain would of course also qualify for equivalence provisions, though as mentioned above they do not cover all areas of financial legislation and can also be withdrawn, which potentially could be a major of source of uncertainty.
In any case, after enactment of the ‘Great Repeal Bill’ any effort to achieve equivalence will become a lot harder, as relevant legislation would need to be passed again. Of course, there is always the hope of securing a bespoke deal, which, as far as I can tell, is the UK government’s current strategy. If anyone is interested in the finer details of this topic, this European Parliament Briefing provides some more colour: http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2016/587369/IPOL_BRI(2016)587369_EN.pdf  -------- In my opinion, the only chance for a soft Brexit is a country like Germany pushing for EU concessions in a bespoke deal, as even the Switzerland model would not be compatible with some of the UK's objectives (e.g. full control of immigration, no EU laws).  However, I think the probability is low, as the EU is going to be wary of the precedent that is being set by Brexit. Any concessions on the four fundamental freedoms as prerequisites for single market access are going to cause serious issues in negotiations with member states and third countries down the line. Even then, it is important to remember, that any member state will be able to block the final deal.
Just a couple of likely contenders:
Considering its enduring issues with the Catalan independence movement, Spain cannot, in my opinion, allow any deal to be too favourable, considering the precedent it would set.
Eastern member states, on the other hand, will look very closely at any immigration concessions.
And then there is Belgium with its regional parliaments, which almost blocked CETA.
(One should also remember, that some people on the EU’s side of the table actually believe in the EU as a peace project and will not take too kindly to a country approaching it like a slightly better Free-Trade Agreement.) But. For all of this to be even remotely probable, there needs to be serious convergence between the EU’s and the UK’s negotiating positions – especially once the final exit bill (EUR 60bn?) is put to the UK. Of course, until a definitive ruling, there is always the possibility of Art. 50 being revocable (a pity, that the UK Supreme Court did not ask the ECJ for an opinion on this). Reading the treaty, one would not think so, but stranger things have happened. However, UK domestic politics would need to shift considerably for this to happen.

The House of Lords could plausibly cause delays - but the overwhelming support for triggering Article 50 in the Commons, combined with the conclusive referendum result, means that doing so would be likely to have substantial political costs: i.e its abolition or radical (and it must be said overdue) reform. When it comes to the real constitutional balance of powers the Lords has a weak hand that it will not overplay. The new support for Brexit is the latest case of the old story of the British Establishment absorbing those it formerly opposed (the anti-EU "bastards") and essentially accepting their arguments. For the first time in decades the Conservative Party is united over Europe - while Labour is split. The  Lib Dem Peers will try to delay as much as they can - but their party's marginal representation in the Commons now means they don't really have a leg to stand on. While the party that actually has been providing substantive opposition in the Commons - the Scots Nats - don't have any Lords.... It should go through as planned by May.

How U K Parliament Might Vote on Article 50 If Court Orders It Hutton (2017) January 23, states that: Britain’s Supreme Court rules Tuesday on whether Prime Minister Theresa May needs to get Parliament’s approval before she triggers Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty to begin negotiating the U.K.’s departure from the European Union. What might the verdict mean?
What might the Supreme Court demand?
The 11 judges could rule in her favor, agreeing that she doesn’t need Parliament’s backing. Or they could require her to put either a motion or a bill before legislators at Westminster.
What’s the difference?
A motion would be a short statement that only members of the House of Commons would be asked to vote on to signal their agreement with Brexit. A bill is a tougher proposition: both chambers of Parliament, including the unelected House of Lords, would be asked to pass a law giving May the power to pull Britain out of the EU.
How long would the process take?
Debates on a motion in the Commons usually last half a day. Given the significance of the motion, Speaker John Bercow might extend that to a whole day, or even two.
If it’s a bill, the process is much more complex. There are a series of stages in each chamber, with votes at each stage, and lots of opportunities for dissenters to propose amendments. Both houses must agree on the wording of the final law.
In theory, bills can complete the entire parliamentary process in a single day. But that’s only happened in emergencies and where there’s cross-party agreement. In the last week or so the EU, David Davis, Liam Fox and Mrs May have all commented on matters that effect this question. The EU has suggested that the 2 year leaving period that starts with A50 is in reality 18 months to negotiate plus 6 months for all parties (the EU, the EU Parliament and the nation states) to ratify and plan to implement. They have also pointed out that ideally  the UK needs to have left the EU before the next EU Parliamentary elections due in May 2020.  David Davis has pointed out that until the French and German elections are out of the way no substantive negotiations regarding the UK's future relationship with the EU can start. May has repeated her aim to invoke A50 before 31st March. If these 3 sets of dates are taken together we would have A50 by 31st Mar 2017, but no substantive negotiations would start until (probably) the end of September 2017. As the 2 year period would end in February 2019, the negotiations would need to be complete by September 2018 (to give the 6 months to ratify). This seems to show that the period to do the negotiations would be September 2017 to September 2018, which is of course 1 year.  A few days ago Fox said that the UK might want to be in the Customs Union, and it appears that Nissan was probably told something similar. But Fox's idea is that the UK is both in a Customs Union and is free to negotiate deals with other countries for products no covered by the Customs Union. The EU does not currently have a pick-and-mix customs union with anyone so this would be a new idea for both the UK and EU. 

May today said (to a Parliamentary Committee) that the negotiations will not be for the UK to fit into any existing EU formulation that comes with exiting rules and institutions (not the EU, not the EEA, not the existing Customs Union) but a totally new legal construct that is a customs union, but outside the oversight of the EU Court of Justice, that includes many relationships with EU security, research, academic organisations.  Considering that it has taken 6 months and that it will take at least another 2 months for Davis to get the ideas of what the UK wants from the negotiations formulated it requires a huge level of optimism to think that there is any chance of reaching an agreement with the EU with only 1 year of negotiations. It was painfully clear from May's answer to the Parliamentary Committee (both Remainers and Leaver) that the UK objectives are still far from thought through. Many of the UK's ideas are contradictory and totally at odds with the stated positions of the EU. (Still a lot of having cake and eating it).  For example May seemed to not grasp that businesses are not going to wait until the day before the UK leaves to find out if transitional period will apply, they need years to plan and if they are being told they might have a different relationship with the EU from April 2019 they will start moving from London in 2017. When asked what would happen if she triggered A50 and two years later no deal with the EU had been agreed, she had no answer.   One can imagine years of arguments about which products will be inside the customs union and which will not. Only a dictator could hope to knock heads together to get such a complete negotiation completed in year. So why is the UK government setting out on a project timetable that has almost zero chance of being achievable?  It could be that May really believes she can achieve it, I find it difficult to accept that. It could be that she has got caught up with events; she has got on the runaway train and does not know how to stop it without crashing. I think this is quite likely. She could be banking on external forces derailing the timetable allowing her to claim she has been stopped from delivering Brexit within her table. I think this is the most likely explanation. I think she hopes that Parliament will stop or delay the process. If it does this before A50 or not is questionable.  Judging by May's performance today I think it is highly likely that Parliament will step in. It was clear that Committee members both for Remain and Leave were not at all convinced by her answers.

Greg Clerk on the Andrew Marr TV program today said that he had written to Nissan to tell them that the UK would be aiming for a tariff free and free flowing arrangement to allows cars and car parts to go to and from the EU. The only arrangements that appear to match his description would be the EU Customs Unions (on a similar basis to Turkey) or the EU Single Market (like Norway). He also spoke of the need to have similar arrangements for other industries and services.  He and May appear to have done a remarkable job of convincing Nissan, that a few weeks previously had said it would not invest in its UK plant without compensation in case tariffs were introduced on Brexit. Bearing in mind that compensation for tariffs is illegal under WTO and EU rules, the UK government seems to be very committed now to the Single Market or the Customs Union. In both cases there exists a more or less standard agreement to sign up to, which it is unlikely that the rest of the EU would object to. But as May and Clerk must be aware both these options preclude the EU making 3rd party trade deals without EU agreement and they both require that the EU Courts enforce the EU set rules. It does not really seem feasible that any agreement like Clerk was describing could operate without a common set of rules and a Court of some kind to deal with disputes. We know the sort of time it takes to create a bespoke trade deal (7 to 10 years seems typical). The UK will (probably) only have two years to do its deal with the EU. So I would suggest that the only possible deal that could be done in 2 years would be to take an existing EU deal such as the Customs Union or Single Market. Maybe with the long term objective of gradually changing it. But in order to do that I am sure that the UK could only get a variation of the Freedom of Movement for Workers and would still need to contribute to the EU budget. The alternative would be no deal at all. Would May be willing to tell Nissan and the motor industry and any other industries that had also been "assured" that there would be no financial or other tariffs that the UK had turned down an offer from the EU for staying in the Customs Union or Single Market? How could the UK "compensate" them? I would not like to be in her shoes if she did not bring a tariff free deal from Brussels. I think "assuring"  Nissan that May can deliver has made it impossible not to.  And that only an existing agreement can be used in the time frame. That said it would be better to get the uncertainty out of the way and start the process by March. As the issue of immigrants has already blurred into not counting the skilled, graduates, students and vital unskilled workers, it should not be impossible to sort out an acceptable fudge.

Whether Article 50 notice is conditional and can be withdrawn by the UK has become an issue on the political side and also in the Brexit legal challenge.  That was one of the High Court’s first questions in oral arguments on Oct. 13.  Also, Donald Tusk has indicated that the UK could withdraw Article 50 notice if they are not pleased with the outcome of the Brexit negotiations with the EU.  On the legal side, my understanding is that the UK court (either the lower court currently hearing the case--called “High Court”-- or the UK Supreme Court when the case is appealed) can “certify the question” to the Court of Justice of the EU.  This means the UK court can ask that the EU court answer the question of whether Article 50 notice can be withdrawn and, if so, how that is accomplished because these are questions of European law, not UK law. The UK court can certify the question if the answer affects the domestic law issue of whether Parliament must pass legislation to invoke Art. 50.   One might wonder if this sort of punting of the question to another court is unusual.  In the United States, federal courts regularly certify questions of state law to the relevant state supreme court, wait for the answer, and then proceed with the rest of the federal case.  The idea behind it is that the other court is in a better position to make the decision on that particular issue.  Also, in the Brexit case, the UK courts are not in a position to enforce against the EU an interpretation made by the UK court about EU law.  That is key.  This decision must be made in a way that binds the EU to the interpretation. Possible legal outcomes:  1.  High Court rules, appeal to UK Supreme Court follows with no EU court involvement. 2.  High court certifies question to EU Court and waits on ruling from EU Court before ruling on UK issues.  An appeal to UK Supreme Court on Parliament involvement is possible. 3.  High court rules without certifying, appeal to UK Supreme Court follows.  Supreme Court certifies the question to EU Court and waits on ruling from EU Court before deciding UK legal questions.   If UK Supreme Court rules for Parliament’s involvement, then that will add more hurdles to the Article 50 notice.   I am still researching and learning about this issue because it came to my attention after reading some of last week’s court transcripts and Tusk’s speech.  The idea that a third court (or more?  Not sure about any appeal process with the EU court) could now become involved in the Brexit litigation could mean further delay.   For more info, see  1. If A50 is invoked before the (so called) Great Repeal Bill (actually a consolidation bill that transfers EU law in to British law) there is a legal problem. As I understand it A50 gives a country up to 2 years to complete its negotiations to leave the EU. At the end of the two years EU treaties shall cease to apply to the Leaving country. 
Therefore it appears to be the case that if the EU invoked A50 in March 2017 all EU Treaties will cease to apply by March 2019 at the latest. I would have thought that if the EU Treaties were just allowed to lapse there would be legal chaos. Hence the need for the Consolidation Law to convert EU law into UK law. But the only way to guarantee that the Consolidation Law is in fact passed before the UK leaves the EU is to pass it before triggering Article 50. Not passing the Consolidation Law before triggering Article 50 appears to be relying on future legislation, which the government may expect to pass, but that there is no way of knowing will pass. Therefore it would appear that in order to protect UK Citizens as well as Citizens of other UK countries legally residing in the UK (who presumably could after March 2017 be classified illegal aliens) A50 has to come after the Consolidation bill. I would assume that many other rights that are provided by EU law would disappear. 
It does not sound right for the Royal Prerogative  (A50) to be used in such a way that Parliament is forced to pass future legislation like it or not. This seems to negate the point of having a Parliament.

The procedure required to invoke Article 50 is an unsettled question under UK law and is now the subject of a number of lawsuits.  The Plaintiffs who are suing argue that they will lose rights and privileges protected by UK statutes upon the triggering of Article 50 and only Parliament has the power to revoke those rights through legislation.  The Prime Minister (PM) says she can invoke under a concept known as the royal prerogative.  The royal prerogative is not well defined by law, even though it is the basis for much of the PM’s power to conduct foreign affairs. The Courts hearing the cases will decide if the royal prerogative standing alone is enough under UK law or whether Parliament must pass legislation before Article 50 can be invoked.   On October 4 and 5, the Belfast High Court will hold a hearing in the Northern Ireland case.  The most pressing legal issues are whether Parliament must pass legislation to invoke Article 50 and whether the Northern Ireland Assembly must consent before Article 50 is filed.  See http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/legal-challenge-to-brexit-to-be-heard-at-belfast-high-court-1.2785486 .  On October 8, the Court in London will hear a number of individual cases that have been consolidated.  The main legal issue in those cases is whether Parliament must pass legislation to trigger Article 50.  See http://www.wsj.com/articles/first-legal-challenge-to-the-u-k-s-brexit-gets-underway-1468947382 and https://jonworth.eu/brexitcalendar/ . These cases will have appeals to the UK Supreme Court for a final decision.  Articles I have read suggest a ruling by the Supreme Court should come down by the end of the year or early next year.   If the Supreme Court holds that Parliament must pass legislation, I may move more to “Not before July 2017” in case of a drawn-out fight or even full rejection of the referendum results.  I plan to update after the October hearings and hope to have a better idea by then of the strength of each side’s arguments and likelihood of success at the Supreme Court.

UK political leaders will need to act sooner rather than later on Article 50 because of pressure from the business community to reduce uncertainty.  The dilemma is painful. The more the UK government takes time to think through the options, educate the public, and deal with opposing views, the longer it will be before the negotiations begin and the uncertainty over the final outcome is dispelled. As far as I understand, one issue is that it is up to the UK to trigger A50, but doing so is to their disadvantage: once triggered, it starts a 2-year period for the exit to be negotiated (trade deals, etc). After 2 years, even if negotiations fail, the UK is out. Failed negotiations means the UK suddenly having no preferred access to EU markets; it would be an economic disaster. Thus, once A50 is invoked, the UK would be under heavy pressure to accept any trade deal proposed by the EU. There's a "loophole" whereby the UK can invoke A50 but take it back if negotiations aren't going its way [1]. But I predict that no UK politician would want to be seen as "taking back Brexit", especially not the Brexiters currently at the helm. The other notable issue I'm aware of is Scotland & Northern Ireland. They wanted to stay in the EU and now threaten secession if Brexit happens. The likely timing of getting any agreement from the EU will to some extent depend on the European national election cycle. France has a general election in Apr/May 2017. The French government will not want to agree a deal with the UK that appears in any way to reward the UK for holding its referendum, as there are calls in France for a Frexit referendum. The UK is unlikely to agree a deal that punishes the UK. So this indicates that stalemate will continue until after May 2017. 
Germany has a general election some time between August and October 2017. Germany may be less determined to punish the UK, but their government will not want to appear weak just before their elections. So I see a small possibility of very quick deal being struck before November 2016, almost no chance between February and May 2017 with a higher probability after the German general election.  What could upset this calculation is an economic crash in the UK, but this could just as easily lead to abandoning Brexit as accepting any deal offered by the EU.  The new UK government structure appears have put the leading Brexit MPs in jobs where they are being challenged to deliver Brexit in the way that they promised (trade deals with the EU and lots of other countries) which most experts believed was very unlikely. This means that if the architects of Brexit fail to deliver the new UK government can reasonably claim that they tried their best and if they failed it was because the Brexit promise was a lie, not because the government ignored the outcome of the referendum. Then via a new election Brexit can be abandoned. Or a deal that neither really satisfies nor horrifies voters such as the UK transferring to  EFTA and a fudge on the Movement of People can be agreed with the EU.
The longer it takes, the less likely it will be that it will happen soon (counting from that point on), or at all.

Although Theresa May has said 'not before the end of this year', I don't think she thought that the leadership battle would be resolved so quickly. I'm weighing three factors here. First, Britain gains very little by prolonged uncertainty. Second, she has made it clear that there is no going back, but that she will only invoke Article 50 when she and her team are ready for the negotiation. Third, what will be the likely outcome of the constitutional challenge? On the second: she's going to have her team in place a lot sooner than she thought, so I expect them to be ready sooner than she originally thought. On the third, it's complicated. I suspect that even though parliament favours remaining, the majority will vote to support invoking Article 50 should they win the constitutional challenge. Many parliamentarians have said that the will of the people ought to be supported even if they were personally for 'remain'.  If it weren't for the complications of the constitutional challenge, I'd be even closer to 100 on the Article being invoked this year.
